newsitem.title: ROMANIA: Romania to cut 1997 budget gap to 4.5 pct/GDP - PM.
newsitem.headline: Romania to cut 1997 budget gap to 4.5 pct/GDP - PM.

text.p: Romania's Prime Minister Victor Ciorbea said on Friday that his centrist coalition government would cut the 1997 state budget deficit to 4.5 percent of gross domestic product, from 1996's 5.8 percent.
The deficit figure for 1997 was agreed during loans talks with the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, Ciorbea told a meeting with leaders of his National Peasant party.
Ciorbea said that the government would announce a tough programme next Monday, aimed at stepping up market reforms, with one-third of the 1997 budget going to social security.
The budget bill -- a plank of loan talks with the World Bank and IMF -- would be presented to parliament later this month, he said.
Both lenders had withheld loans to Romania last year over foreign exchange market curbs and overspending by the former ruling leftists in an election year.
The 1996 state budget gap was far in excess of the 2.2 percent target agreed with the Fund.

Ciorbea, whose centrist coalition ousted ex-communists in last November's elections, has pledged tight policies to contain surging deficits and inflation, to boost efforts to put the economy on a free-market footing.
